topic.title: Quick start
topic.p: The current version of %product% (%product-version%) provides linters that let you analyze Java, Kotlin, Groovy, PHP, JavaScript, TypeScript, C#, Visual Basic, C, C++, Python, and Golang projects. In addition, you can inspect your code using various features.
You have the following options for running %product% on your local machine:

chapter.title: Run Qodana in your IDE
chapter.p: Starting from version 2023.2, %product% is available in IntelliJ IDEA and PyCharm (both the Professional and Community editions), PhpStorm, WebStorm, GoLand, and Rider.
chapter.tip: You do not need to buy a separate %product% license to run it in the IDE.
chapter.p: Here is the short video showing how you can run %product% in your IDE.
Here is the description of all steps shown in this video:

list.li: In your IDE, navigate to the Problems tool window.
In the Problems tool window, click the Server-Side Analysis tab.
On the Server-Side Analysis tab, click the Start Qodana button.
In the window that opens, click the Try locally button, and then click Run.

li.p: On the Server-Side Analysis tab, you can overview inspection results. It also contains two links in the upper part of the tab.

img.alt: Links on the Server-Side Analysis tab

tab.title: Open Qodana report in browser
tab.p: Open the inspection report in an intuitive and easy-to-use form.

tab.title: Add Qodana to CI/CD pipeline
tab.p: Open the configuration wizard for using %product% in CI/CD pipelines.
To learn more about %product% and CI/CD pipelines, see the section.

chapter.title: Prerequisites
chapter.p: Depending on your license, you probably need to obtain a trial license and accomplish the onboarding stage at Qodana Cloud.
In this section, you will be using a project token available after creating a Qodana Cloud project. To learn more about it, see the section.

chapter.title: Run Qodana
chapter.p: Qodana provides two options for local analysis of your code. Qodana CLI is the easiest option to start. Alternatively, you can use the Docker command from the Docker image tab.
